problem: It takes four painters working at the same rate $1.25$ work-days to finish a job. If only three painters are available, how many work-days will it take them to finish the job, working at the same rate? Express your answer as a mixed number.
model_solution:
Step 1: Let x be the number of work-days required to finish the job with three painters.
Let 1/4 of the job be completed per day by each of the four painters.
Let 1/3 of the job be completed per day by each of the three painters.
Step 2: Since four workers can complete $\frac{1}{4}$ of the job per day, four workers can complete the entire job in $4\cdot \frac{4}{1}=16$ days.
$4\text{ workers} \cdot \frac{1}{4}\text{ job/day} = 1\text{ job/16 days}.$
Since three workers can complete $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job per day, three workers can complete the entire job in $3\cdot \frac{3}{1}=9$ days.
$3\text{ workers} \cdot \frac{1}{3}\text{ job/day} = 1\text{ job/9 days}.$
Step 3: $\frac{1}{4}$ of the job is completed per day by 4 workers, so $\frac{1}{16}$ of the job is completed per day by 1 worker. $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job is completed per day by 3 workers, so $\frac{1}{9}$ of the job is completed per day by 1 worker. Since 3 workers can complete $\frac{1}{9}$ of the job per day, we can set up the following proportion: $\frac{1}{4} \cdot 4 = \frac{1}{9} \cdot x$
$\frac{1}{9} \cdot x= \frac{1}{4} \cdot 4 \Rightarrow x=\frac{1}{9} \cdot \frac{16}{1}=\frac{16}{9}$
Step 4: $\frac{16}{9}=\boxed{1\frac{7}{9}}$
Step 5: $\frac{1}{9} \cdot x= \frac{1}{4} \cdot 4 \Rightarrow x=\frac{1}{9} \cdot \frac{16}{1}$
Step 6: $\frac{1}{9} \cdot x = \frac{1}{4} \cdot 4 \Rightarrow x = \frac{1}{9} \cdot \frac{16}{1} = \frac{16}{9}$
Step 2: To set up the equation, multiply the number of work-days by the fraction of the job that can be completed per day by each of the three painters: $x\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)=\left(\frac{4}{1}\right)\left(\frac{1.25}{1}\right)$
$\frac{1}{3} x = 5$
Step 3:
$\frac{1}{3}x = 5 \Rightarrow x = 5 \cdot 3$
$x = 15$
steps:
Step 1: Let x be the number of work-days required to finish the job with three painters.
Let 1/4 of the job be completed per day by each of the four painters.
Let 1/3 of the job be completed per day by each of the three painters.

Step 2: Since four workers can complete $\frac{1}{4}$ of the job per day, four workers can complete the entire job in $4\cdot \frac{4}{1}=16$ days.
$4\text{ workers} \cdot \frac{1}{4}\text{ job/day} = 1\text{ job/16 days}.$
Since three workers can complete $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job per day, three workers can complete the entire job in $3\cdot \frac{3}{1}=9$ days.
$3\text{ workers} \cdot \frac{1}{3}\text{ job/day} = 1\text{ job/9 days}.$

Step 3: $\frac{1}{4}$ of the job is completed per day by 4 workers, so $\frac{1}{16}$ of the job is completed per day by 1 worker. $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job is completed per day by 3 workers, so $\frac{1}{9}$ of the job is completed per day by 1 worker. Since 3 workers can complete $\frac{1}{9}$ of the job per day, we can set up the following proportion: $\frac{1}{4} \cdot 4 = \frac{1}{9} \cdot x$

Step 2: To set up the equation, multiply the number of work-days by the fraction of the job that can be completed per day by each of the three painters: $x\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)=\left(\frac{4}{1}\right)\left(\frac{1.25}{1}\right)$
full_steps:
Step 1: Let x be the number of work-days required to finish the job with three painters.
Let 1/4 of the job be completed per day by each of the four painters.
Let 1/3 of the job be completed per day by each of the three painters.

Step 2: Since four workers can complete $\frac{1}{4}$ of the job per day, four workers can complete the entire job in $4\cdot \frac{4}{1}=16$ days.
$4\text{ workers} \cdot \frac{1}{4}\text{ job/day} = 1\text{ job/16 days}.$
Since three workers can complete $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job per day, three workers can complete the entire job in $3\cdot \frac{3}{1}=9$ days.
$3\text{ workers} \cdot \frac{1}{3}\text{ job/day} = 1\text{ job/9 days}.$

Step 3: $\frac{1}{4}$ of the job is completed per day by 4 workers, so $\frac{1}{16}$ of the job is completed per day by 1 worker. $\frac{1}{3}$ of the job is completed per day by 3 workers, so $\frac{1}{9}$ of the job is completed per day by 1 worker. Since 3 workers can complete $\frac{1}{9}$ of the job per day, we can set up the following proportion: $\frac{1}{4} \cdot 4 = \frac{1}{9} \cdot x$

Step 2: To set up the equation, multiply the number of work-days by the fraction of the job that can be completed per day by each of the three painters: $x\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)=\left(\frac{4}{1}\right)\left(\frac{1.25}{1}\right)$
